Riding in Cars With Black Boys

Is my body enough, am I powerful enough, to make being alive a threat?

Austin Monroe
Apr 24

Indiana

We were 10, maybe 15 minutes from the Kentucky state line. I was driving my car from Chicago to Charlotte, and had asked Jake to come along. This was the first time he would meet my parents, and the first time I would visit home since we moved in together. It was a moment I had only imagined: The kind of mundane milestone — meeting the parents — that felt so remote and impossible when I came out to myself in seventh grade, and even less possible when my coming out was met with a verbatim recitation of Leviticus a few years later.

Jake agreeing to a 15-hour road trip shocked me. He has the exact opposite reaction of puppies when it comes to car rides. His whole body stiffens, he gets uncharacteristically quiet, fidgety, and hyperaware. I agreed to do most of the driving. I get into a rhythm after the first 30 minutes of a marathon drive, and I wanted him to be as relaxed as possible. I said, “Hey, let’s put on ‘Kitty Girl.’” Season 3 of RuPaul’s Drag Race All Stars had just ended, and the queens’ verses always lit him up.

It worked like a charm. He snaked his body in the passenger seat, cranked the volume up, and scream-sang every lyric. Just as Kennedy Davenport was directing us to feel our puss down deep in our souls, a racket of blue and red light seized us. I hadn’t been speeding; I switched over to cruise control, as I typically do on long rides, a few miles back. My registration was up-to-date, as was the insurance. I changed lanes a while ago, but the metronome tick of my turn signal was fresh in my mind. I know I signaled. I always do.

“Do you know why I pulled you over?”

I didn’t.

“You made an illegal lane change back there.”

I hadn’t, but telling the truth to cops can be risky. Let’s just get this over with, I thought.

“License and registration, please.”

I robotically handed him the already-plucked-from-the-glove-compartment documentation — you don’t want a cop to see you reach. The officer took my identifiers, started toward his parked car — blue and red light still shrieking — and got in.

I don’t know how police treat queer Black and Jewish people in Almost-Kentucky, Indiana, and I didn’t want to find out.

He returned a few gut-wrenching minutes later. “What are you boys up to?”

I let him know we were driving back to my hometown to leave my car with my parents. “I don’t need it in Chicago,” I explained. I tried to sound casual, like I was making conversation in the checkout line. I didn’t mention that Jake and I were partners. I don’t know how police treat queer Black and Jewish people in Almost-Kentucky, Indiana, and I didn’t want to find out.

“Do you have any guns or drugs in the car?”

Wait… What? It took my brain a few beats to catch up to what was happening. “Uhhh… no, sir. No guns. No drugs,” I said, trying to sound casual. I think I wedged a laugh between my voice and the officer. I looked at him this time. He was stocky in a fit way, about the same height as me with steel blue eyes that pop off the slight scarlet of his cheeks. He had heavily gelled blond hair and a fresh military fade on the sides. He looked like a cop. He went back to his squad car for a few moments, then reappeared in a flash.

“Do you mind stepping out of the vehicle?”

Do I have an option? Is this a trick question? I asked if something was wrong. He assured me this was just routine. I’m sure that it is.

This was the first car I ever bought. It wasn’t a hand-me-down my parents generously passed along after getting whatever utility they could out of it. Its use wasn’t negotiated with a brother or sister. It was mine — paid for with my money, the fruits of my adult life. I loved that car. And here I was, beckoned out of its safety and warmth into an unseasonably cold Indiana afternoon.

Maybe I didn’t signal, I thought.

I thought I was about to die. From the rush of adrenaline that was plugging my air passages and surging blood through my ears, sure, but also in a Ferguson or Southside or Cleveland or Oakland or Falcon Heights or Sanford kind of way. I betrayed myself, and I knew it, not that I had much of a choice. I hovered above us. I watched myself follow this man, this strange, confused man, to a squad car for doing absolutely the fuck nothing. I tried to justify his behavior — Maybe this is routine, he’s just doing his job — and I hated myself for this betrayal. I hated him even more for quizzing me on my personal fidelity.

I thought back to when I had first moved to Chicago. I traveled a similar stretch of highway, my Jeep packed with my most cherished possessions: the faggy club looks and jockstraps, the plant babies I had rescued and nurtured into a jungle, my journals, books on Buddhist philosophy and Black femme brilliance. I thought back to the six-hour stretch of road across Ohio and how I didn’t see any other brown faces on it, how I thought to myself, Be careful. Stay alert. Don’t get stopped out here.

We reached the silver and black Crown Victoria, lights still branding me a problem. The cop opened the driver’s side door and settled in. He reached across the wide body of the cruiser, unlatched the passenger door, and pushed it open for me. “Get in, Mr. Monroe.” Mister. A sign of respect. He was being nice, I guess. I wasn’t handcuffed, so I wasn’t under arrest. I got in, as if under a spell, as if throwing myself to the wolves, and pulled the door shut behind me. “I’d let you in the back, but Regina’s with me today.” I looked back to see a German Shepherd spread across the roomy backseat. She perked her black and brown ears up and gave me a quizzical, head-cocked glance. She and I have the same color eyes, I thought.

I had never been in a police car before. Apparently they have dirty floor mats and cracked, faux-leather seats. So I sat there in the passenger seat instead of in the back like a criminal, which I was not. I reached for a seatbelt and felt silly for doing so. Me and Regina and an overeager cop joyriding off into the Indiana afternoon.

For all the money allocated to police departments, you’d think they’d have better technology. The officer woke up a rhinoceros of a laptop. I could see flashes of his screen out the corner of my eye. I saw the word WARRANT in bright red serif blaze across the top of his screen. I understood what was happening now, and I felt stupid that it took me this long to locate a feeling other than total surrender. The “illegal lane change” was pretext to stop me. Surely, I was a criminal. Surely something would pop up.

The old ass computer takes an approximate eternity to load. In the eon it takes to send its electronic tentacles through the ether to verify my acceptability, I begin to wonder: What if something’s there? What if he does find something?

Who had made me into a villain, and why did I go along with it so easily?

I wondered if the assumption that I’m a dangerous criminal was enough to make it so. I had done a lot of blow in college with the rich white kids. Would that show up? Would Regina smell my youthful indiscretion? Is my body enough, am I powerful enough, to make being alive a threat? While the old warrant database churned and processed, the cop was nice, making conversation, trying to get me to unwittingly confess to a crime I hadn’t committed.

“Where are you from?”

“Oh, I hear North Carolina’s nice.”

“How do you boys know each other?”

“Oh, where’d you go to school?”

“Oh, that’s a good school. How long have you known him?”

“Where’d you say you were going again?”

“Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”

“How long are you going to be there?”

“Mom and Dad excited to have you home, huh?”

“Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”

“How’d you say you know him, again?”

“What’s his name?”

“Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”

“Where are you coming from?”

“Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”

“Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”

His one-man Good Cop, Bad Cop song and dance dizzied me. A navy blue Impala sped up, then slowed to a halt on the driver’s side. The officer waved the car on. Nothing came up on the warrant search. I was relieved.

What did I think was going to be there? Who had made me into a villain, and why did I go along with it so easily? Of course nothing was there.

“Alright, sit tight for a second. I’m just gonna go ask Mister… Jacob, was it? a few questions. You’re sure there are no guns or drugs in the car?”

I nod no? Shake my head yes? This phrasing tripped me up, which was maybe the point. I didn’t know how to answer. He exited the vehicle. I looked back at Regina, metal grating between us. She’s a political prisoner, I told myself, forced to dehumanize and hunt down people with the same colored eyes as her.

The officer returned, this time with Jake’s ID. Riding in cars with Black boys is suspicious in this part of Indiana, enough so to warrant a spin through the state and national warrant registry. I stifled a scoff at the ridiculousness and pageantry of the whole ordeal. Me and my sweet Jake, two outlaw faggots on a clandestine mission to transport molly and poppers through rural Indiana. Up to no good, up to something, surely.

Nothing comes up for Jake.

“Okay, one moment.”

The officer sauntered up to the passenger side of my car, Jake’s side. They exchanged a few words. Jake later told me the officer had asked him the same questions he asked me: “How do you know each other? For how long? Where are you going? Where were you coming from, again? Going to North Carolina, huh? And where are you from originally? Oh, Iowa! Good people in Iowa! How do you all know each other again? How’d you meet?” He hadn’t asked Jake about guns or drugs.

This is what power looked like for him, and he gleefully surveyed the fruits of his birthright….

I saw him open Jake’s door. Then I saw Jake step out onto the gravel. Jake later told me the officer made him leave our phones in the car. He had been on the line with his friend Clark, a lawyer back in Chicago, to give him a play-by-play of what had gone down. Until the cop made him put the phone down.

“People are using those things as tasers these days.”

Jake thought I was going to die. Well, I will die someday. Dying is passive, natural, something we can celebrate, even relish. Death is something to look forward to and make arrangements for, a vantage point from which we survey the hills and valleys of our lives and gently, quietly exit this place. So, Jake didn’t think I was going to die. Jake thought I was going to be killed — actively and intentionally. There would be no evidence, no video, no documentation. His word against the cop’s. No phones. No footage. No proof. No trial. A hashtag for one, maybe two weeks.

When he escorted Jake from the passenger seat and walked him about 30 yards north of my car, I, too, thought I was going to be killed. When the officer found a spot sufficiently far from the car, and from me, he planted Jake, pivoted languidly, and ambled back towards me, towards his idling chariot with the screaming lights. I tried the door. Nothing. I don’t know what would have happened had I been able to exit. Maybe I’d become trouble, out of order, something to be put back in its place. Maybe he’d just shoot me already and get it over with, reconstruct the narrative after the deed was done. Didn’t matter. I was stuck. I was resolved to the coming killing. If I must add my name to the laundry list of those who have had their bodies snatched, those who were deemed problems in need of solving, then I must. Then fear. This is what power looked like for him, and he gleefully surveyed the fruits of his birthright, the hundred-or-so yard expanse he had claimed as a site of his dominance. I was his Plymouth Rock, his New World.

He finally made it back to the police cruiser.

“Jake seems nice.”

Fuck you, I thought.

I saw Jake’s ID and mine propped against the upturned screen of the laptop and missed him deeply.

“Alright, Mr. Monroe. We’re just about done here. Just to ask one more time, you sure there aren’t any guns or drugs in the car?”

“No,” I spat. I could barely speak. If I opened my mouth, I didn’t know what would come out. The tempest brewing in me threatened to hoist itself up my lattice of ribs, scale the soft flesh of my esophagus, and destroy my body before he has the chance to. I might scream and claw my way out, swipe at his saggy, red jowls, gouge his stone blue eyes from his face. I might become the monster, the criminal, the aggressor. I might give him a reason, the reason he’s been looking for, that he has been taunting me to give him.

Instead I said, “There are no guns in the car.”

Maybe being cutesy will work.

“I’ve never even held a gun, let alone used one.”

No laugh. Tough crowd.

The officer flipped my registration between his index and middle fingers. He found whatever he was looking for and punched in some information on his laptop. He wants me. He wants to cuff me, hogtie me, and toss me, unbuckled, into the body-sized backseat. He wants to watch Regina pounce all over me, and jostle me to and fro on the way to some cold cage in Whereverthefuck, Indiana.

About an hour has passed since my “illegal lane change.”

I want to take fistfuls of gravel and side-of-the-road grit and rain down confetti over me and over Jake and over my car. I want to stomp and scream and jump and curse and yell.

Nothing comes up in his final, desperate database search. If you’re not going to kill me, and you’re not going to shackle me, then let me go. I wanted to get through as much of Appalachia as we could before dark. I wanted Jake to see the purple redbud blossoms and the shower of white serviceberry flowers and the rhapsody of dogwood blooms in the warm, golden, fading evening sun. I promised him it would make the whole drive worth it, and this Protector and Server was messing up the whole plan. I wanted Jake to see the brown and tan and grey earth jutting up and cutting the sky into manageable, us-sized pieces. I wanted him to see how freeing it was to weave your way up and down and through the winding mountains, to come out the other side onto flat, sure land.

But instead, I am in an unvacuumed police cruiser, deciphering radio chatter, awaiting my fate.

“Are we almost done here?”

“Shouldn’t be too much longer. And you’re sure there are no guns in the car?”

No.

“Okay, no guns, but any weapons at all?”

No.

He exits the car, circles around back and stops at Regina’s door. Her resting body animates and she stands at full attention, ready to follow orders. Fake ass bitch, I think. The officer peels open the door, lobs a few commands at her, and latches the leash at the nape of her neck. He escorts her over to my car like they’re on homecoming court. He’s excited, I can tell. He thinks I am going to be his grand finale, crown him prince. He leads Regina around the perimeter of my car in a slow, excruciating dirge.

Nothing.

Maybe a second pass will do the trick. He opens the front passenger door and lets her poke her head in.

Nothing.

He opens the rear passenger door, and she dutifully hops up and sniffs around.

Nothing.

Then the rear driver’s side door, then the driver’s door.

No guns. No drugs.

He walks Regina back to the car and pats her butt up into the diner-booth backseat. He walks around to the driver’s side, opens the door, and settles in. He hands me my registration and our ID cards.

“Thanks for your patience, Mr. Monroe. You’re free to go.”

Yeah, no shit.

He pops the lock, and I open the door. I want to fall to my knees, kiss the sandy ground, taste my freedom. I want to take fistfuls of gravel and side-of-the-road grit and rain down confetti over me and over Jake and over my car. I want to stomp and scream and jump and curse and yell. I want to throw rocks at the police cruiser, demand answers from the officer and from Regina.

But instead I walk, jelly-kneed, back to my car. I motion for Jake to come back and hand him his ID. I walk around to the driver’s side, silent, and get into my car. I close the door, buckle my seat belt, start the engine, and let it idle. I put RuPaul back on, but it’s not the same. It feels cruel, like a fantasy world that I do not, cannot, inhabit.

We’re quiet for a while. I feel weightless, like maybe I was killed back there. Like maybe this is the Jeep Compass chariot to heaven. Like maybe I imagined the whole thing.

We made it to the mountain before dark. Jake thought the flowers were pretty, and so did I. I was happy to be here, happy to be able to see the pretty flowers.

When It’s Time

I’ve decided that I want to die. Not now, but when it’s time. I want to grow old. I want to get really, really old and wrinkly and have a gorgeous crown of grey, kinky hair. I want tons of sweet dogs and grandchildren crawling over me, hanging from my arms, clung to my sturdy legs, laughing and playing, carefree and joyful. I want a grandkids-sized house that always smells like cooked food and sweet something-or-the-other. I want a big yard with a big garden. I want to plunge my old hands into the soft, cool earth and feel the land under my nails. I want my palms to smell like rosemary and sage and soil. I want to see my features and body soften, to ebb and flow and tell the stories of where I’ve been and the life I’ve led. I want to look back over my hills and valleys, over my Appalachian mountain, and know that I survived this, I somehow made it. I want to be here long enough to die.

“When It’s Time” was inspired by the 2015 poem “When I’m Old, a Garden” by Jamila Reddy. Find her work here and here.

  • LGBTQ
  • Race
  • Equality
  • Justice
  • Eyes

  • Austin Monroe

    Austin is a writer and student living in New York. Pronouns: he/they Instagram: austinmonroe.biz

  • Human Parts

title: Riding in Cars With Black Boys

“No,” I spat. I could barely speak. If I opened my mouth, I didn’t know what would come out. The tempest brewing in me threatened to hoist itself up my lattice of ribs, scale the soft flesh of my esophagus, and destroy my body before he has the chance to. I might scream and claw my way out, swipe at his saggy, red jowls, gouge his stone blue eyes from his face. I might become the monster, the criminal, the aggressor. I might give him a reason, the reason he’s been looking for, that he has been taunting me to give him.

Instead I said, “There are no guns in the car.”

Maybe being cutesy will work.

“I’ve never even held a gun, let alone used one.”

No laugh. Tough crowd.

The officer flipped my registration between his index and middle fingers. He found whatever he was looking for and punched in some information on his laptop. He wants me. He wants to cuff me, hogtie me, and toss me, unbuckled, into the body-sized backseat. He wants to watch Regina pounce all over me, and jostle me to and fro on the way to some cold cage in Whereverthefuck, Indiana.

About an hour has passed since my “illegal lane change.”

I want to take fistfuls of gravel and side-of-the-road grit and rain down confetti over me and over Jake and over my car. I want to stomp and scream and jump and curse and yell.

Nothing comes up in his final, desperate database search. If you’re not going to kill me, and you’re not going to shackle me, then let me go. I wanted to get through as much of Appalachia as we could before dark. I wanted Jake to see the purple redbud blossoms and the shower of white serviceberry flowers and the rhapsody of dogwood blooms in the warm, golden, fading evening sun. I promised him it would make the whole drive worth it, and this Protector and Server was messing up the whole plan. I wanted Jake to see the brown and tan and grey earth jutting up and cutting the sky into manageable, us-sized pieces. I wanted him to see how freeing it was to weave your way up and down and through the winding mountains, to come out the other side onto flat, sure land.

But instead, I am in an unvacuumed police cruiser, deciphering radio chatter, awaiting my fate.

“Are we almost done here?”

“Shouldn’t be too much longer. And you’re sure there are no guns in the car?”

No.

“Okay, no guns, but any weapons at all?”

No.

He exits the car, circles around back and stops at Regina’s door. Her resting body animates and she stands at full attention, ready to follow orders. Fake ass bitch, I think. The officer peels open the door, lobs a few commands at her, and latches the leash at the nape of her neck. He escorts her over to my car like they’re on homecoming court. He’s excited, I can tell. He thinks I am going to be his grand finale, crown him prince. He leads Regina around the perimeter of my car in a slow, excruciating dirge.

Nothing.

Maybe a second pass will do the trick. He opens the front passenger door and lets her poke her head in.

Nothing.

He opens the rear passenger door, and she dutifully hops up and sniffs around.

Nothing.

Then the rear driver’s side door, then the driver’s door.

No guns. No drugs.

He walks Regina back to the car and pats her butt up into the diner-booth backseat. He walks around to the driver’s side, opens the door, and settles in. He hands me my registration and our ID cards.

“Thanks for your patience, Mr. Monroe. You’re free to go.”

Yeah, no shit.

He pops the lock, and I open the door. I want to fall to my knees, kiss the sandy ground, taste my freedom. I want to take fistfuls of gravel and side-of-the-road grit and rain down confetti over me and over Jake and over my car. I want to stomp and scream and jump and curse and yell. I want to throw rocks at the police cruiser, demand answers from the officer and from Regina.

But instead I walk, jelly-kneed, back to my car. I motion for Jake to come back and hand him his ID. I walk around to the driver’s side, silent, and get into my car. I close the door, buckle my seat belt, start the engine, and let it idle. I put RuPaul back on, but it’s not the same. It feels cruel, like a fantasy world that I do not, cannot, inhabit.

We’re quiet for a while. I feel weightless, like maybe I was killed back there. Like maybe this is the Jeep Compass chariot to heaven. Like maybe I imagined the whole thing.

We made it to the mountain before dark. Jake thought the flowers were pretty, and so did I. I was happy to be here, happy to be able to see the pretty flowers.

When It’s Time

I’ve decided that I want to die. Not now, but when it’s time. I want to grow old. I want to get really, really old and wrinkly and have a gorgeous crown of grey, kinky hair. I want tons of sweet dogs and grandchildren crawling over me, hanging from my arms, clung to my sturdy legs, laughing and playing, carefree and joyful. I want a grandkids-sized house that always smells like cooked food and sweet something-or-the-other. I want a big yard with a big garden. I want to plunge my old hands into the soft, cool earth and feel the land under my nails. I want my palms to smell like rosemary and sage and soil. I want to see my features and body soften, to ebb and flow and tell the stories of where I’ve been and the life I’ve led. I want to look back over my hills and valleys, over my Appalachian mountain, and know that I survived this, I somehow made it. I want to be here long enough to die.

“When It’s Time” was inspired by the 2015 poem “When I’m Old, a Garden” by Jamila Reddy. Find her work here and here.
title_html: Riding in Cars With Black Boys
content: Riding in Cars With Black Boys  Is my body enough, am I powerful enough, to make being alive a threat?     Austin Monroe  Blocked  Unblock   Follow  Following     Apr 24                    Illustration:  Jacob Rochester     Indiana  We were 10, maybe 15 minutes from the Kentucky state line. I was driving my car from Chicago to Charlotte, and had asked Jake to come along. This was the first time he would meet my parents, and the first time I would visit home since we moved in together. It was a moment I had only imagined: The kind of mundane milestone — meeting the parents — that felt so remote and impossible when I came out to myself in seventh grade, and even less possible when my coming out was met with a verbatim recitation of Leviticus a few years later.  Jake agreeing to a 15-hour road trip shocked me. He has the exact opposite reaction of puppies when it comes to car rides. His whole body stiffens, he gets uncharacteristically quiet, fidgety, and hyperaware. I agreed to do most of the driving. I get into a rhythm after the first 30 minutes of a marathon drive, and I wanted him to be as relaxed as possible. I said, “Hey, let’s put on ‘Kitty Girl.’” Season 3 of  RuPaul’s Drag Race    All Stars   had just ended, and the queens’ verses always lit him up.  It worked like a charm. He snaked his body in the passenger seat, cranked the volume up, and scream-sang every lyric. Just as Kennedy Davenport was directing us to feel our puss down deep in our souls, a racket of blue and red light seized us. I hadn’t been speeding; I switched over to cruise control, as I typically do on long rides, a few miles back. My registration was up-to-date, as was the insurance. I changed lanes a while ago, but the metronome tick of my turn signal was fresh in my mind. I know I signaled. I always do.  “Do you know why I pulled you over?”  I didn’t.  “You made an illegal lane change back there.”  I hadn’t, but telling the truth to cops can be risky.  Let’s just get this over with  , I thought.  “License and registration, please.”  I robotically handed him the already-plucked-from-the-glove-compartment documentation — you don’t want a cop to see you reach. The officer took my identifiers, started toward his parked car — blue and red light still shrieking — and got in.  I don’t know how police treat queer Black and Jewish people in Almost-Kentucky, Indiana, and I didn’t want to find out.  He returned a few gut-wrenching minutes later. “What are you boys up to?”  I let him know we were driving back to my hometown to leave my car with my parents. “I don’t need it in Chicago,” I explained. I tried to sound casual, like I was making conversation in the checkout line. I didn’t mention that Jake and I were partners. I don’t know how police treat queer Black and Jewish people in Almost-Kentucky, Indiana, and I didn’t want to find out.  “Do you have any guns or drugs in the car?”  Wait… What?   It took my brain a few beats to catch up to what was happening. “Uhhh… no, sir. No guns. No drugs ,”   I said, trying to sound casual. I think I wedged a laugh between my voice and the officer. I looked at him this time. He was stocky in a fit way, about the same height as me with steel blue eyes that pop off the slight scarlet of his cheeks. He had heavily gelled blond hair and a fresh military fade on the sides. He looked like a cop. He went back to his squad car for a few moments, then reappeared in a flash.  “Do you mind stepping out of the vehicle?”  Do I have an option? Is this a trick question?   I asked if something was wrong. He assured me this was just routine. I’m sure that it is.  This was the first car I ever bought. It wasn’t a hand-me-down my parents generously passed along after getting whatever utility they could out of it. Its use wasn’t negotiated with a brother or sister. It was mine — paid for with my money, the fruits of my adult life. I loved that car. And here I was, beckoned out of its safety and warmth into an unseasonably cold Indiana afternoon.  Maybe I didn’t signal  , I thought.  I thought I was about to die. From the rush of adrenaline that was plugging my air passages and surging blood through my ears, sure, but also in a Ferguson or Southside or Cleveland or Oakland or Falcon Heights or Sanford kind of way. I betrayed myself, and I knew it, not that I had much of a choice. I hovered above us. I watched myself follow this man, this strange, confused man, to a squad car for doing absolutely the fuck nothing. I tried to justify his behavior —  Maybe this is routine, he’s just doing his job   — and I hated myself for this betrayal. I hated him even more for quizzing me on my personal fidelity.  I thought back to when I had first moved to Chicago. I traveled a similar stretch of highway, my Jeep packed with my most cherished possessions: the faggy club looks and jockstraps, the plant babies I had rescued and nurtured into a jungle, my journals, books on Buddhist philosophy and Black femme brilliance. I thought back to the six-hour stretch of road across Ohio and how I didn’t see any other brown faces on it, how I thought to myself,  Be careful. Stay alert. Don’t get stopped out here.   We reached the silver and black Crown Victoria, lights still branding me a problem. The cop opened the driver’s side door and settled in. He reached across the wide body of the cruiser, unlatched the passenger door, and pushed it open for me. “Get in, Mr. Monroe.” Mister. A sign of respect. He was being nice, I guess. I wasn’t handcuffed, so I wasn’t under arrest. I got in, as if under a spell, as if throwing myself to the wolves, and pulled the door shut behind me. “I’d let you in the back, but Regina’s with me today.” I looked back to see a German Shepherd spread across the roomy backseat. She perked her black and brown ears up and gave me a quizzical, head-cocked glance.  She and I have the same color eyes  , I thought.  I had never been in a police car before. Apparently they have dirty floor mats and cracked, faux-leather seats. So I sat there in the passenger seat instead of in the back like a criminal, which I was not. I reached for a seatbelt and felt silly for doing so.  Me and Regina and an overeager cop joyriding off into the Indiana afternoon  .  For all the money allocated to police departments, you’d think they’d have better technology. The officer woke up a rhinoceros of a laptop. I could see flashes of his screen out the corner of my eye. I saw the word WARRANT in bright red serif blaze across the top of his screen. I understood what was happening now, and I felt stupid that it took me this long to locate a feeling other than total surrender. The “illegal lane change” was pretext to stop me. Surely, I was a criminal. Surely  something   would pop up.  The old ass computer takes an approximate eternity to load. In the eon it takes to send its electronic tentacles through the ether to verify my acceptability, I begin to wonder:  What if something’s there? What if he does find something?   Who had made me into a villain, and why did I go along with it so easily?  I wondered if the assumption that I’m a dangerous criminal was enough to make it so. I had done a lot of blow in college with the rich white kids. Would that show up? Would Regina smell my youthful indiscretion? Is my body enough, am I powerful enough, to make being alive a threat? While the old warrant database churned and processed, the cop was nice, making conversation, trying to get me to unwittingly confess to a crime I hadn’t committed.  “Where are you from?”  “Oh, I hear North Carolina’s nice.”  “How do you boys know each other?”  “Oh, where’d you go to school?”  “Oh, that’s a good school. How long have you known him?”  “Where’d you say you were going again?”  “Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”  “How long are you going to be there?”  “Mom and Dad excited to have you home, huh?”  “Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”  “How’d you say you know him, again?”  “What’s his name?”  “Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”  “Where are you coming from?”  “Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”  “Do you have any drugs or guns in the car?”  His one-man Good Cop, Bad Cop song and dance dizzied me. A navy blue Impala sped up, then slowed to a halt on the driver’s side. The officer waved the car on. Nothing came up on the warrant search. I was relieved.  What did I think was going to be there? Who had made me into a villain, and why did I go along with it so easily? Of course nothing was there.  “Alright, sit tight for a second. I’m just gonna go ask Mister… Jacob, was it? a few questions. You’re sure there are no guns or drugs in the car?”  I nod no? Shake my head yes? This phrasing tripped me up, which was maybe the point. I didn’t know how to answer. He exited the vehicle. I looked back at Regina, metal grating between us.  She’s a political prisoner,   I told myself,  forced to dehumanize and hunt down people with the same colored eyes as her  .  The officer returned, this time with Jake’s ID. Riding in cars with Black boys is suspicious in this part of Indiana, enough so to warrant a spin through the state and national warrant registry. I stifled a scoff at the ridiculousness and pageantry of the whole ordeal. Me and my sweet Jake, two outlaw faggots on a clandestine mission to transport molly and poppers through rural Indiana. Up to no good, up to something, surely.  Nothing comes up for Jake.  “Okay, one moment.”  The officer sauntered up to the passenger side of my car, Jake’s side. They exchanged a few words. Jake later told me the officer had asked him the same questions he asked me: “How do you know each other? For how long? Where are you going? Where were you coming from, again? Going to North Carolina, huh? And where are you from originally? Oh, Iowa! Good people in Iowa! How do you all know each other again? How’d you meet?”    He hadn’t asked Jake about guns or drugs.  This is what power looked like for him, and he gleefully surveyed the fruits of his birthright….  I saw him open Jake’s door. Then I saw Jake step out onto the gravel. Jake later told me the officer made him leave our phones in the car. He had been on the line with his friend Clark, a lawyer back in Chicago, to give him a play-by-play of what had gone down. Until the cop made him put the phone down.  “People are using those things as tasers these days.”  Jake thought I was going to die. Well, I will die someday. Dying is passive, natural, something we can celebrate, even relish. Death is something to look forward to and make arrangements for, a vantage point from which we survey the hills and valleys of our lives and gently, quietly exit this place. So, Jake didn’t think I was going to die. Jake thought I was going to be killed — actively and intentionally. There would be no evidence, no video, no documentation. His word against the cop’s. No phones. No footage. No proof. No trial. A hashtag for one, maybe two weeks.  When he escorted Jake from the passenger seat and walked him about 30 yards north of my car, I, too, thought I was going to be killed. When the officer found a spot sufficiently far from the car, and from me, he planted Jake, pivoted languidly, and ambled back towards me, towards his idling chariot with the screaming lights. I tried the door. Nothing. I don’t know what would have happened had I been able to exit. Maybe I’d become trouble, out of order, something to be put back in its place. Maybe he’d just shoot me already and get it over with, reconstruct the narrative after the deed was done. Didn’t matter. I was stuck. I was resolved to the coming killing.  If I must add my name to the laundry list of those who have had their bodies snatched, those who were deemed problems in need of solving, then I must.   Then fear. This is what power looked like for him, and he gleefully surveyed the fruits of his birthright, the hundred-or-so yard expanse he had claimed as a site of his dominance. I was his Plymouth Rock, his New World.  He finally made it back to the police cruiser.  “Jake seems nice.”  Fuck you  , I thought.  I saw Jake’s ID and mine propped against the upturned screen of the laptop and missed him deeply.  “Alright, Mr. Monroe. We’re just about done here. Just to ask one more time, you sure there aren’t any guns or drugs in the car?”  “No ,”   I spat. I could barely speak. If I opened my mouth, I didn’t know what would come out. The tempest brewing in me threatened to hoist itself up my lattice of ribs, scale the soft flesh of my esophagus, and destroy my body before he has the chance to. I might scream and claw my way out, swipe at his saggy, red jowls, gouge his stone blue eyes from his face. I might become the monster, the criminal, the aggressor. I might give him a reason, the reason he’s been looking for, that he has been taunting me to give him.  Instead I said, “There are no guns in the car.”  Maybe being cutesy will work.  “I’ve never even held a gun, let alone used one.”  No laugh. Tough crowd.  The officer flipped my registration between his index and middle fingers. He found whatever he was looking for and punched in some information on his laptop. He wants me. He wants to cuff me, hogtie me, and toss me, unbuckled, into the body-sized backseat. He wants to watch Regina pounce all over me, and jostle me to and fro on the way to some cold cage in Whereverthefuck, Indiana.  About an hour has passed since my “illegal lane change.”  I want to take fistfuls of gravel and side-of-the-road grit and rain down confetti over me and over Jake and over my car. I want to stomp and scream and jump and curse and yell.  Nothing comes up in his final, desperate database search.  If you’re not going to kill me, and you’re not going to shackle me, then let me go  . I wanted to get through as much of Appalachia as we could before dark. I wanted Jake to see the purple redbud blossoms and the shower of white serviceberry flowers and the rhapsody of dogwood blooms in the warm, golden, fading evening sun. I promised him it would make the whole drive worth it, and this Protector and Server was messing up the whole plan. I wanted Jake to see the brown and tan and grey earth jutting up and cutting the sky into manageable, us-sized pieces. I wanted him to see how freeing it was to weave your way up and down and through the winding mountains, to come out the other side onto flat, sure land.  But instead, I am in an unvacuumed police cruiser, deciphering radio chatter, awaiting my fate.  “Are we almost done here?”  “Shouldn’t be too much longer. And you’re sure there are no guns in the car?”  No.  “Okay, no guns, but any weapons at all?”  No.  He exits the car, circles around back and stops at Regina’s door. Her resting body animates and she stands at full attention, ready to follow orders.  Fake ass bitch  , I think .   The officer peels open the door, lobs a few commands at her, and latches the leash at the nape of her neck. He escorts her over to my car like they’re on homecoming court. He’s excited, I can tell. He thinks I am going to be his grand finale, crown him prince. He leads Regina around the perimeter of my car in a slow, excruciating dirge.  Nothing.  Maybe a second pass will do the trick. He opens the front passenger door and lets her poke her head in.  Nothing.  He opens the rear passenger door, and she dutifully hops up and sniffs around.  Nothing.  Then the rear driver’s side door, then the driver’s door.  No guns. No drugs.  He walks Regina back to the car and pats her butt up into the diner-booth backseat. He walks around to the driver’s side, opens the door, and settles in. He hands me my registration and our ID cards.  “Thanks for your patience, Mr. Monroe. You’re free to go.”  Yeah, no shit.  He pops the lock, and I open the door. I want to fall to my knees, kiss the sandy ground, taste my freedom. I want to take fistfuls of gravel and side-of-the-road grit and rain down confetti over me and over Jake and over my car. I want to stomp and scream and jump and curse and yell. I want to throw rocks at the police cruiser, demand answers from the officer and from Regina.  But instead I walk, jelly-kneed, back to my car. I motion for Jake to come back and hand him his ID. I walk around to the driver’s side, silent, and get into my car. I close the door, buckle my seat belt, start the engine, and let it idle. I put RuPaul back on, but it’s not the same. It feels cruel, like a fantasy world that I do not, cannot, inhabit.  We’re quiet for a while. I feel weightless, like maybe I was killed back there. Like maybe this is the Jeep Compass chariot to heaven. Like maybe I imagined the whole thing.  We made it to the mountain before dark. Jake thought the flowers were pretty, and so did I. I was happy to be here, happy to be able to see the pretty flowers.    When It’s Time  I’ve decided that I want to die. Not now, but when it’s time. I want to grow old. I want to get really, really old and wrinkly and have a gorgeous crown of grey, kinky hair. I want tons of sweet dogs and grandchildren crawling over me, hanging from my arms, clung to my sturdy legs, laughing and playing, carefree and joyful. I want a grandkids-sized house that always smells like cooked food and sweet something-or-the-other. I want a big yard with a big garden. I want to plunge my old hands into the soft, cool earth and feel the land under my nails. I want my palms to smell like rosemary and sage and soil. I want to see my features and body soften, to ebb and flow and tell the stories of where I’ve been and the life I’ve led. I want to look back over my hills and valleys, over my Appalachian mountain, and know that I survived this, I somehow made it. I want to be here long enough to die.    “When It’s Time” was inspired by the 2015 poem “When I’m Old, a Garden” by Jamila Reddy. Find her work   here    and   here   .
